template.title: 1. {company_name}'s Financial Position Analysis
template.section_1:
The analysis given below on {company_name}’s financial state and operating efficiency is made for the period
{start_date} to {end_date} based on the financial statements data prepared according to Generally
Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP).

template.title: 1.1. Structure of the Assets and Liabilities
template.section_1:
According to the data in the table above, the share of {company_name}’s current assets equaled about a ({ct_assets_last_yr_obs_per_value}%) on
the last day of the period analyzed ({end_date}), while non-current assets equaled ({nct_assets_last_yr_obs_per_value}%) of all assets.
An {assets_yoy_chg_ind_1} in assets to ${assets_last_yr_obs}m (${assets_yoy_chg}m) was seen during the reviewed period (from {start_date} to
{end_date}). This {equity_yoy_chg_ind_1} of the equity value is a factor which {equity_yoy_chg_ind_2} describes the dynamics of
{company_name}’s financial state.
The total {assets_yoy_chg_ind_3} of {company_name}’s assets primarily connected with the value {cause_chg_ind_1} of the item {cause_name} by
${cause_yoy_chg}, that made {cause_yoy_per_chg}% of all {cause_chg_ind_2} changed assets.
The most significant {el_yoy_chg_ind} of sources of finance (“Equity and Liabilities”) is seen on the following rates
(the percentages from total equity and liabilities change is shown in brackets).

template.title: 1.2. Net Assets(Net Worth)
template.section_1:
The net tangible assets equaled ${nta_last_obs}m on the last day of the period analyzed. The net tangible assets
significantly {nta_chg_ind} (by {nta_per_chg}%) for the entire period reviewed. The intangible assets were equal to
${ita_last_obs}m at the end of the period reviewed. In addition, the increase tendency is also confirmed by a
{nta_trend_ind} trend. This value shows the difference between the value of net tangible assets and all net worth.
The net worth (net assets) value is used as one of the tools to estimate the company's value (used together with other methods, such as discounted cash flow method, or an estimation based on shareholder's value
etc.). But it is a key value in the estimation of the company's financial condition.

template.title: 1.3 Financial Sustainability Analysis
template.header_1: 1.3.1. Key ratios of the {company_name}'s financial sustainability
template.section_1:
First, attention should be drawn to the debt-to-equity ratio and debt ratio as the ratios describing the capital
structure. Both ratios have similar meaning and indicate if there is not enough capital (equity) for stable work
for the company. Debt-to-equity ratio is calculated as a relationship of the borrowed capital (liabilities) to theequity, while debt ratio is calculated as a relationship of the liabilities to the overall capital (i.e. the sum of
equity and liabilities).
The debt-to-equity equaled {dte_last_yr_obs} at the end of the period analyzed. At the end of the period reviewed, the
debt ratio was equal to {debt_ratio_last_yr_obs}. An change in the debt ratio was {debt_ratio_yoy_change} during the entire period analyzed.
The Capital structure of the {company_name} is demonstrated in the chart below:
template.section_2:
According to common rules, non-current investments should be made, in the first place, with the help of the most stable source of financing, i.e. with the help of own capital (equity). The non-current assets to Net
worth ratio shows if this rule is followed. The ratio notably {nca_to_nw_ratio_yoy_chg_ind} to {nca_to_nw_ratio_yoy_chg} during the period analyzed. On
{end_date}, the ratio shows an {nca_to_nw_ratio_state} value.
The current liability ratio {ct_lib_ratio_last_yr_obs} shows that long-term debts make about {ltd_last_yr_obs} on the last day of the period
analyzed ({end_date}), while short-term liabilities make {stl_last_yr_obs} of the total liabilities of the company.
The following chart demonstrates the dynamics of the main ratios of financial stability of {company_name}.
template.section_3:
The working capital was equal to ${wc_last_yr_obs}m on the last day of period analyzed ({end_date}), which
considerably {wc_yoy_chg_ind} ($ {wc_first_yr_obs} m) the level of the working capital on the first day ({start_date}). According to
calculations, working capital {wc_yoy_chg_ind_2} covers the inventories of the company and is deemed to be a {wc_yoy_chg_ind_3}
factor. The inventory to working capital ratio equaled {in_to_wc_last_obs} on last day of period analysed ({end_date}). It
{in_to_wc_yoy_chg_ind_1} describes the company's financial state and says about {in_to_wc_yoy_chg_ind_2} long-term sources of
financing, but in some cases it can be caused with warehouse inventories that are too {inventory_yoy_chg_ind}.

template.title: 1.4. Liquidity Analysis
template.section_1:
Liquidity related ratios are one of the most widespread indicators of a company's solvency. There are three
liquidity related ratios: current ratio, quick ratio and cash ratio. Current ratio is one of the most widespread
and shows to what degree the current assets of the company are meeting the current liabilities. The
solvency of the company for the near future is described with the quick ratio which reflects if there are
enough funds for normal execution of current transactions with creditors. The table below demonstrates all
three liquidity ratios for {company_name}.
template.section_2:
The current ratio amounted to {ct_ratio_last_obs} on {end_date}; that is {ct_ratio_first_obs}  {ct_ratio_yoy_chg_ind_1} than on {start_date}. The value of the ratio can be characterized as {ct_ratio_yoy_chg_ind_2} on {end_date}. During the whole of the evaluated period, the
current ratio kept a {ct_ratio_yoy_chg_ind_3} value.
The quick ratio was seen to go {quick_ratio_yoy_chg_ind_1} from {quick_ratio_first_obs} to {quick_ratio_first_obs} for the period reviewed ({start_date} - {end_date}).
During the reviewed period, multidirectional changes in the ratio (both growth and decrease) were verified.
The value of the quick ratio can be described as {quick_ratio_yoy_chg_ind_2} on {end_date}. It means that {company_name} has {quick_ratio_yoy_chg_ind_3}
assets which can be transferred to cash in a very short time to meet current liabilities.
The value of the third ratio, the cash ratio, is similar to the two previous ratios, lies in the {cash_ratio_yoy_chg_ind_1} range at the end of the period analyzed. Company is observed to have {cash_ratio_yoy_chg_ind_2} cash and cash equivalents to meet
rrent liabilities.

other_info.Debt to equity ratio:
A debt­to­equity
ratio is calculated
by taking the
total liabilities
and dividing it by
shareholders' equity.
It is the key
financial ratio
and used as a
standard for judging
a company's financial
standing.
Acceptable value:
no more than 1.5
(optimum 0.43­1)
other_info.Debt ratio:
A debt ratio is
calculated by dividing
total liabilities
(i.e. long-term and
short-term liabilities)
by total assets.
It shows how much
the company relies
on debt to finance
assets (similar to
debt-to-equity ratio).
Normal value:
0.6 or less
(optimum 0.3-0.5).
other_info.Long-term debt to equity ratio:
This ratio is
calculated by
dividing long-term
(non-current)
liabilities by
equity.
other_info.Non-current assets to net worth:
This ratio is
calculated by
dividing long-term
(non-current) assets
by net worth
(equity) and
measures the extent
of a company's
investment in low-
liquidity non-current
assets.
This ratio is
important for
comparison analysis
because it's less
dependent on
industry (structure
of company's assets)
than debt ratio
and debt-to-equity
ratio.
Acceptable value:
no more than 1.25.
other_info.Capitalization ratio:
Calculated by
dividing non-current
liabilities by the
sum of equity
and non-current
liabilities.
other_info.Fixed assets to net worth:
This ratio indicates
the extent to which
the owners' cash
is frozen in the
form of fixed
assets, such as
property, plant, and
equipment, investment
property and
non-current biological
assets.
Acceptable value:
no more than 0.75.
other_info.Current liability ratio:
Current liability
ratio is calculated
by dividing
current liabilities by
total (i.e. current
and non-current) liabilities.
other_info.Change In Working Capital:
Working capital
(net working capital),
Million Dollar
other_info.Inventory to working capital ratio:
Inventory to working
capital ratio (2:1)
Acceptable value:
1 or less.
other_info.Current ratio:
The current ratio
is calculated by
dividing current assets
by current liabilities.
It indicates a company's
ability to meet
short-term debt obligations.
Acceptable value:
2 or more.
other_info.Cash Ratio:
Cash ratio is
calculated by dividing
absolute liquid assets
(cash and cash equivalents)
by current liabilities.
Normal value: 0.2 or more.
other_info.Quick ratio:
The quick ratio is
calculated by dividing
liquid assets
(cash and cash equivalents,
trade and other
current receivables,
other current financial
assets) by current
liabilities.
It is a measure of
a company's ability
to meet its
short-term obligations
using its most liquid
assets (near cash
or quick assets).
Normal value:
1 or more.

template.title: 2.1. Overview of the Financial Results
template.section_1:
The table below gives information about the main financial results of {company_name}’s activities for the period
analyzed (from {start_date} to {end_date}).
template.section_2:
The revenue equaled ${revenue_last_obs}m for the last year {end_date}, though  the  revenue  was  {revenue_yoy_chg_ind_1} ${revenue_first_obs}m 
(i.e.  the  {revenue_yoy_chg_ind_2}  equalled  ${revenue_yoy_chg}m). Despite multidirectional changes in the revenue, it was verified
that its' {revenue_yoy_chg_ind_3} was up on the whole. The chart below demonstrates the change in revenue and a
comprehensive income for {company_name}. The gross profit amounted to ${gross_profit_last_obs}m for the last year. During the
analyzed period, it was observed that there was an obvious {gross_profit_yoy_change_ind_1} in the gross profit of ${gross_profit_yoy_change}m or of
{gross_profit_yoy_per_change}%.
During the last year ({end_date}), the company posted a gross profit and earnings before interest and taxes(EBIT), which was ${combined_last_obs_1}m. The comprehensive income of {company_name} was ${com_inc_last_obs} in total for the current year
{end_date}.

graph_data.title: Dynamics of revenue and net profit

template.title: 2.2. Profitability Ratios
template.section_1:
For the last period {end_date}, the company {gross_margin_yoy_chg_ind} gross profit and {operating_margin_yoy_chg_ind} from operational and financial
activities, which became a reason for {profitability_ratios_values_ind} values of all three profitability ratios given in the table for this
period. During the period {start_date}, the gross margin amounted to {gm_last_obs}%, which is much {gm_yoy_chg_ind} ({gm_yoy_per_change}%)
than for the period {end_date}.
The profitability calculated by earnings before interest and taxes (Return on sales) is more important from a comparative analyses point of view. During the last period, {end_date}, the return on sales was {operating_margin_last_yr_obs}% per annum, and profitability calculated by net profit was {profit_margin_last_yr_obs}% per annum.
template.section_2:
To assess the liabilities that the company should repay for the use of borrowed capital, an interest coverage ratio was calculated. The acceptable value is deemed to be not less than 1.5. In this case, the interest coverage ratio was {icr_last_year_obs} during the last period, {end_date}, which is evidence of “{company_name}’s” capability (inability)
to pay interest on borrowed assets. It should be considered that not all interest payments are necessarily
included on the income statement. In certain cases, interest is included in investments in non-current asset
and as a result it is not used to calculate the indicated ratio.
template.section_3:
For the period analyzed, the return on assets {roa_yoy_chg_ind_1} from {roa_first_obs}% to {roa_last_obs}% (by {roa_yoy_chg_val}%). During the evaluated
period, multidirectional changes in the return on assets (both growth and reduction) were observed; The
return on assets mainly kept a {roa_ind_1} value during the whole of the analyzed period, none the less it
turned out to be {roa_ind_2} the norm for the last period {end_date}.
One of the most important ratio of business profitability is the return on equity (ROE), which reflects the
profitability of investments by the owners. The return on equity for {company_name} during the period {end_date} was
{roe_last_obs}% per annum. Such a {roe_yoy_chg_ind} rate is evidence of {roe_yoy_chg_ind} business profitability, but it can also depend on
internal macroeconomic conditions, under which the company works (for example, inflation rate, interest
rates, etc).
The following chart demonstrates the dynamics of the main rates of return on total assets and equity
of “{company_name}” for the period analyzed (from {start_date} to {end_date}).

template.title: 2.3. Analysis of the Business Activity (Turnover Ratios)
template.section_1:
To assess {company_name}’s business activity, the table below provides the main rates of turnover: receivables,
inventory, current and total assets turnovers; accounts payable and capital turnovers of the company.
Turnover ratios have strong industry specifics and depend on activity. This is why an absolute value of the
ratios does not permit making a qualitative assessment.
When assets turnover ratios are analyzed, an increase in ratios (i.e. velocity of circulation) and a reduction
in circulation days are deemed to be positive dynamics. There is no well-defined interaction for accounts
payable and capital turnover. In any case, an accurate conclusion can only be made after the reasons that
caused these changes are considered.
template.section_2:
* Calculation in days. Ratio value is equal to 365 divided by days outstanding.

 For last year, the average collection period (Days Sales Outstanding) was {dso_last_obs} days and the average days payable outstanding was {dpo_last_obs} days as shown in the table. The
rate of asset turnover means that {company_name}’s  gains revenue equal to the sum of all the available assets every
365 days (on average during the entire period analyzed).

other_info.ROE:
ROE is calculated by
taking a year's worth
of earnings (net profit)
and dividing them by
the average shareholder
equity for that period,
and is expressed as
a percentage.
It is one of the
most important financial
ratios and profitability
metrics. Acceptable value:
 no less than 12%.
other_info.ROA:
ROA is calculated
by dividing net income
by total assets,
and displayed as a
percentage.
Acceptable value:
6% or more.
other_info.ROIC:
ROCE / ROIC is
calculated by dividing
EBIT by capital employed
(equity plus non-current
liabilities).It indicates the
efficiency and profitability
of a company's capital
investments.
other_info.Interest coverage ratio:
Reference:
Interest coverage
ratio (ICR).
Acceptable value:
no less than 1.5.

template.title: 3.1. Key Ratios Summary
template.section_1: The main financial state indicator values and {company_name}'s activity results are classified by qualitative assessment according to the results of the analysis for the entire period reviewed and are given below.

section_2.excellent: The analysis revealed the following excellent financial characteristics:
section_2.fair: The analysis revealed the following good financial characteristics:
section_2.poor: The analysis revealed the following poor financial characteristics:
section_2.critical: The analysis revealed the following critical financial characteristics:
section_2.Quick ratio:
An {ratio_state} relationship between liquid assets (current assets minus inventories) and current liabilities
(quick ratio is {ratio_last_obs}).

template.title: 3.2. Rating of the Financial Position and Financial Performance of {company_name}
template.section_1:
According to the analytical results given above, the following qualitative assessments were calculated:
{company_name} 's financial position score is {finan_pos_score} the financial performance score for the last two years is {finan_per_score}.
According to the rating scale, it is AAA (excellent position) and B (satisfactory financial performance),
respectively.These scores are obtained considering both key ratios at the end of the period analyzed and
the dynamics of the ratios, including their expected values for the next year. Based on these two scores, the
final rating score of  {company_name} 's financial condition was calculated. The financial condition was assessed at the A rate (good).
An ‘A’ rating shows a good financial condition of a company and its' capability to meet their likely current
liabilities. Companies with this rating refer to the category of the borrowers who can obtain credits with high
probability (good creditworthiness).
